entry.title: 0068: Names Scores
entry.content:
The following problem is taken from Project Euler.

Using names.txt (right click and ‘Save Link/Target As…’), a 46K text file containing over five-thousand first names, begin by sorting it into alphabetical order. Then working out the alphabetical value for each name, multiply this value by its alphabetical position in the list to obtain a name score.

For example, when the list is sorted into alphabetical order, COLIN, which is worth $3 + 15 + 12 + 9 + 14 = 53$, is the $938th$ name in the list. So, COLIN would obtain a score of $938 × 53 = 49714$.

What is the total of all the name scores in the file?
entry.summary: The following problem is taken from Project Euler.

entry.title: 0067: Amicable Numbers
entry.content:
The following problem is taken from Project Euler.

Let $d(n)$ be defined as the sum of proper divisors of $n$ (numbers less than n which divide evenly into n).

If $d(a) = b$ and $d(b) = a$, where $a \neq b$, then $a$ and $b$ are an amicable pair and each of $a$ and $b$ are called amicable numbers.

For example, the proper divisors of $220$ are $1, 2, 4, 5, 10, 11, 20, 22, 44, 55$ and $110$; therefore $d(220) = 284$. The proper divisors of $284$ are $1, 2, 4, 71$ and $142$; so $d(284) = 220$.

Evaluate the sum of all the amicable numbers under $10000$.
entry.summary: The following problem is taken from Project Euler.

entry.title: 0066: Factorial Digit Sum
entry.content:
The following problem is taken from Project Euler.

$n!$ means $n × (n − 1) × … × 3 × 2 × 1$

For example, $10! = 10 × 9 × … × 3 × 2 × 1 = 3628800$, and the sum of the digits in the number $10!$ is $3 + 6 + 2 + 8 + 8 + 0 + 0 = 27$.

Find the sum of the digits in the number $100!$.
entry.summary: The following problem is taken from Project Euler.

entry.title: 0065: Counting Sundays
entry.content:
The following problem is taken from Project Euler.

You are given the following information, but you may prefer to do some research for yourself.

- 1 Jan 1900 was a Monday.
- Thirty days has September,
April, June and November.
All the rest have thirty-one,
Saving February alone,
Which has twenty-eight, rain or shine.
And on leap years, twenty-nine.
- A leap year occurs on any year evenly divisible by 4, but not on a century unless it is divisible by 400.

How many Sundays fell on the first of the month during the twentieth century (1 Jan 1901 to 31 Dec 2000)?
entry.summary: The following problem is taken from Project Euler.

entry.title: 0064: Number Letter Counts
entry.content:
The following problem is taken from Project Euler.

If the numbers $1$ to $5$ are written out in words: one, two, three, four, five, then there are $3 + 3 + 5 + 4 + 4 = 19$ letters used in total.

If all the numbers from $1$ to $1000$ (one thousand) inclusive were written out in words, how many letters would be used?

NOTE: Do not count spaces or hyphens. For example, $342$ (three hundred and forty-two) contains $23$ letters and $115$ (one hundred and fifteen) contains $20$ letters. The use of “and” when writing out numbers is in compliance with British usage.
entry.summary: The following problem is taken from Project Euler.

entry.title: 0063: Power Digit Sum
entry.content:
The following problem is taken from Project Euler.

$2^15 = 32768$ and the sum of its digits is $3 + 2 + 7 + 6 + 8 = 26$.

What is the sum of the digits of the number $2^1000$?
entry.summary: The following problem is taken from Project Euler.

entry.title: 0062: Lattice Paths
entry.content:
The following problem is taken from Project Euler.

Starting in the top left corner of a 2×2 grid, and only being able to move to the right and down, there are exactly 6 routes to the bottom right corner.

How many such routes are there through a 20×20 grid?
entry.summary: The following problem is taken from Project Euler.

entry.title: 0061: Repeated Numbers
entry.content:
Write a computer program to read 10 integers and prints the repeated integers (which have appeared two or more times).

Input: 0 1 2 4 5 6 7 6 5 6

Output: 5 6
entry.summary: Write a computer program to read 10 integers and prints the repeated integers (which have appeared two or more times).

entry.title: 0060: Population
entry.content:
The country A has 50M inhabitants, and its population grows 3% per year. The country B, 70M and grows 2% per year. Tell in how many years A will surpass B.

(Note: M means Million, $10^6$)
entry.summary: The country A has 50M inhabitants, and its population grows 3% per year. The country B, 70M and grows 2% per year. Tell in how many years A will surpass B.

entry.title: 0059: Dumb Monkey
entry.content:
Write a computer program which computes if this dumb monkey can climb on a pillar or not. Every time this monkey climbs, it goes up 3 ft, and slips by 1 ft, which means he is essentially climbing only 1 ft. He can only climb successfully if exactly 3 fts are remaining from the topmost point. In this case, he will not slip because he has landed on the top point. For the lengths less than 3 ft, he will fall over the pillar, and comes down. The program reads a number P, length of the pillar and prints YES if monkey can successfully climb this pillar, NO otherwise.

Test Case:

10
NO

11
YES
entry.summary: Write a computer program which computes if this dumb monkey can climb on a pillar or not. Every time this monkey climbs, it goes up 3 ft, and slips by 1 ft, which means he is essentially climbing only 1 ft. He can only climb successfully if exactly 3 fts are remaining from the topmost point. In this case, he will not slip because he has landed on the top point. For the lengths less than 3 ft, he will fall over the pillar, and comes down. The program reads a number P, length of the pillar and prints YES if monkey can successfully climb this pillar, NO otherwise.

entry.title: 0058: Next Date
entry.content:
Given as input three integers representing a date as day, month, year, print out the day, month and year for the following day’s date.

Example:

Input: 28 2 1992

Output: 29 2 1992
entry.summary: Given as input three integers representing a date as day, month, year, print out the day, month and year for the following day’s date.

entry.title: 0057: Consecutive Numbers
entry.content:
Write a computer program that reads n, prints following -

If n=3,

1
2  3
4  5  6
entry.summary: Write a computer program that reads n, prints following -

entry.title: 0056: High/Low Number Guessing Game
entry.content: Write a computer program to imitate High-Low Number Guessing Game. The program asks for a number m, and then generates a random number from 1 to m, and then asks user to guess it. The user can enter his guess, and program can respond back by either ‘High’ (if user guess is higher than the program’s number), ‘Low’ or ‘Correct’. The program displays the count of attempts taken by user to correctly guess the number.
entry.summary: Write a computer program to imitate High-Low Number Guessing Game. The program asks for a number m, and then generates a random number from 1 to m, and then asks user to guess it. The user can enter his guess, and program can respond back by either ‘High’ (if user guess is higher than the program’s number), ‘Low’ or ‘Correct’. The program displays the count of attempts taken by user to correctly guess the number.

entry.title: 0055: Ascending or Descending
entry.content: Write a computer program to read a list of 5 numbers and your program should be able to tell whether the list sequence is Ascending, Descending, None.
entry.summary: Write a computer program to read a list of 5 numbers and your program should be able to tell whether the list sequence is Ascending, Descending, None.

entry.title: 0054: Least Difference
entry.content: Write a computer program to read a list of 10 numbers and return those two consecutive numbers from the list whose difference is least among others.
entry.summary: Write a computer program to read a list of 10 numbers and return those two consecutive numbers from the list whose difference is least among others.

entry.title: 0053: Cross and Naught
entry.content: Implement a (Command-line based) 2-player Cross and Naught game in Python.
entry.summary: Implement a (Command-line based) 2-player Cross and Naught game in Python.

entry.title: 0052: Longest Collatz Sequence
entry.content:
The following problem is taken from Project Euler.

The following iterative sequence is defined for the set of positive integers:

$ n → \frac{n}{2} $ ($n$ is even)

$ n → 3n + 1 $ ($n$ is odd)

Using the rule above and starting with $13$, we generate the following sequence:

It can be seen that this sequence (starting at $13$ and finishing at $1$) contains $10$ terms. Although it has not been proved yet (Collatz Problem), it is thought that all starting numbers finish at 1.

Which starting number, under one million, produces the longest chain?

NOTE: Once the chain starts the terms are allowed to go above one million.

entry.title: 0051: Large Sum
entry.summary: The following problem is taken from Project Euler.

entry.title: 0050: Highly Divisible Triangle Number
entry.content:
The following problem is taken from Project Euler.

The sequence of triangle numbers is generated by adding the natural numbers. So the 7th triangle number would be $1 + 2 + 3 + 4 + 5 + 6 + 7 = 28$. The first ten terms would be:

Let us list the factors of the first seven triangle numbers:

     1: 1
     3: 1,3
     6: 1,2,3,6
    10: 1,2,5,10
    15: 1,3,5,15
    21: 1,3,7,21
    28: 1,2,4,7,14,28

We can see that 28 is the first triangle number to have over five divisors.

What is the value of the first triangle number to have over five hundred divisors?
entry.summary: The following problem is taken from Project Euler.

entry.title: 0049: Largest Product in a Grid
entry.content:
The following problem is taken from Project Euler.

In the 20×20 grid below, four numbers along a diagonal line have been marked by square brackets.

08 02 22 97 38 15 00 40 00 75 04 05 07 78 52 12 50 77 91 08
49 49 99 40 17 81 18 57 60 87 17 40 98 43 69 48 04 56 62 00
81 49 31 73 55 79 14 29 93 71 40 67 53 88 30 03 49 13 36 65
52 70 95 23 04 60 11 42 69 24 68 56 01 32 56 71 37 02 36 91
22 31 16 71 51 67 63 89 41 92 36 54 22 40 40 28 66 33 13 80
24 47 32 60 99 03 45 02 44 75 33 53 78 36 84 20 35 17 12 50
32 98 81 28 64 23 67 10[26]38 40 67 59 54 70 66 18 38 64 70
67 26 20 68 02 62 12 20 95[63]94 39 63 08 40 91 66 49 94 21
24 55 58 05 66 73 99 26 97 17[78]78 96 83 14 88 34 89 63 72
21 36 23 09 75 00 76 44 20 45 35[14]00 61 33 97 34 31 33 95
78 17 53 28 22 75 31 67 15 94 03 80 04 62 16 14 09 53 56 92
16 39 05 42 96 35 31 47 55 58 88 24 00 17 54 24 36 29 85 57
86 56 00 48 35 71 89 07 05 44 44 37 44 60 21 58 51 54 17 58
19 80 81 68 05 94 47 69 28 73 92 13 86 52 17 77 04 89 55 40
04 52 08 83 97 35 99 16 07 97 57 32 16 26 26 79 33 27 98 66
88 36 68 87 57 62 20 72 03 46 33 67 46 55 12 32 63 93 53 69
04 42 16 73 38 25 39 11 24 94 72 18 08 46 29 32 40 62 76 36
20 69 36 41 72 30 23 88 34 62 99 69 82 67 59 85 74 04 36 16
20 73 35 29 78 31 90 01 74 31 49 71 48 86 81 16 23 57 05 54
01 70 54 71 83 51 54 69 16 92 33 48 61 43 52 01 89 19 67 48

The product of these numbers is $26 × 63 × 78 × 14 = 1788696$.

What is the greatest product of four adjacent numbers in the same direction (up, down, left, right, or diagonally) in the 20×20 grid?
entry.summary: The following problem is taken from Project Euler.
